Word.targetWord: [vi] to move with a sudden movenment or to make something move in this way Example: the cow's tail flicked from side to side / flick a look/glance at somebody: to look very quickly at somebody or something
Word.Comment: the cow's tail flicked from side to side /I flicked a glance at her watch.

Word.targetWord: extreme sadness, especially because someone you love has died
Word.Comment: The grief she felt over Helen's death was almost unbearable.

Word.targetWord: a large amount of money that is invested or is used to start a business
Word.Comment: to set up a business with a starting capital of £100 000

Word.targetWord: to make a chemical reaction happen faster
to exist in or affect only a particular place or group
Word.Comment: the company's foreign sales are not confined to ASIA.

Word.targetWord: The end of something that was previously considered to be powerful, such as business, industry or system.
to start something, especially something new, difficult, or exciting.
knowledge or understanding of something. / to understand something and consider it when you take action or make a decision
Word.Comment: /kɒg.nɪ.zən/ The lawyer asked the jury to take cognizance of the defendant's generosity in giving to charity

Word.targetWord: to make someone or something have a particular quality, or to believe that they have it
Word.Comment: Her resistance to the Nationalists endowed her with legendary status.

Word.targetWord: to not do or have something pleasant or enjoyable
Word.Comment: I have to forgo lunch

Word.targetWord: A piece of clothing
Word.Comment: /gɑː.mənt/ She pulled the garment on and zipped it up

Word.targetWord: to produce a strong feeling or memory in someone
Word.Comment: /ɪˈvəʊk/ The photographs evoked strong memories of our holidays in France.

Word.targetWord: quiet because people are listening, waiting to hear something, or talking quietly
Word.Comment: A hushed courtroom awaited the verdict

Word.targetWord: willing to allow someone, especially a child, to do or have whatever they want, even if this is not good for them
the way in which the level of your voice changes in order to add meaning to what you are saying, for example by going up at the end of a question
To manage to get something which is hard or difficult to get
Word.Comment: Given that there would a number of such like-minded souls; jobs in the formal sector are hard to come by

Word.targetWord: a period of time or process during which something happens
Word.Comment: During the course of our conversation, it emerged that Bob had been in prison.

Word.targetWord: someone who has been proved to be guilty of a crime and sent to prison
land or field that is covered with grass and is used for cattle, sheep etc to feed on.
Word.Comment: pɑːs.tʃər the lush pastures of the southern countries

Word.targetWord: very careful about small details and always making sure that everything is done correctly
Word.Comment: Their planning and preparation were meticulous.

Word.targetWord: to behave in an embarrassing way that is likely to make other people notice you and laugh at you
to become very successful or very strong and healthy
Word.Comment: plants that thrive in tropical rainforests

Word.targetWord: When people have money and everything that is need for a good life
Word.Comment: prɒsˈper.ɪ.ti a time of economic prosperity

Word.targetWord: The most important character in film, play or story.
to encourage or help an activity to begin or develop further.
Word.Comment: ˈstɪm.jʊ.leɪt the president's plan to stimulate economic growth.

Word.targetWord: If an agreement, law or rule stipulates something, it must be done
Word.Comment: Laws stipulate the maximum interest rate that banks can charge

Word.targetWord: having narrow lines or bands of color.
Word.Comment: straɪˈeɪ.tɪd

Word.targetWord: a situation in which there is not enough of something
Word.Comment: the scarcity of employment opportunities

Word.targetWord: a part of an area of activity, especially of business, trade etc
Word.Comment: Agricultural sector

Word.targetWord: an action that is against religious rules and is considered to be an offence against god.
a single thin piece of thread, wire, hair, etc
Word.Comment: He reached out and brushed a strand of hair away from her face

Word.targetWord: the feeling of being satisfied with your own abilities, and that you deserve to be liked or respected
slow and unwilling
Word.Comment: She gave a reluctant smile.

Word.targetWord: to move or be shaped like waves that are rising and falling.
Word.Comment: undulating hill.

Word.targetWord: when someone is very fat in a way that is unhealthy
an oblong shape has four straight sides at 90 degrees to each other, two of which are longer than the other two.
Word.Comment: ɒb.lɒŋ

Word.targetWord: a fine powder produced by flowers, which is carried by the wind or by insects to other flowers of the same type, making them produce seeds
To officially suggest someone or something for an important position, duty or prize.
Word.Comment: Ferraro was the first woman to be nominated for the job of VP.

Word.targetWord: The usual or normal situation, way of doing something.
Famous for something bad.
when you feel as if you are going to vomit
relating to a woman who is pregnant or who has just had a baby.
Word.Comment: məˈtɜː.nə.ti a maternity dress.

Word.targetWord: a statement that consists of a carefully considered opinion or judgement
Word.Comment: Most people accept the proposition that we have a duty to protect endangered animals.

Word.targetWord: something that people think will make everything better and solve all their problems
